title: Next.js CSR vs SSR vs SSG vs ISR and now PPR!

rawLines.text: Let's talk about some of these terms
that you hear all the time but you may
not completely understand them. So these
are CSR, SSR, SSG, ISR, PPR. This is
actually a bit of a new one. It's coming
along very nicely in Nex.js. Let's
actually try to understand what they all
mean, how it is practically used because
they are actually uh pretty core
features in a NexJS application. So
let's actually start from the left here.
All right. So to understand this you do
need to understand a little bit about uh
how a nextjs app is structured. So we
have a client side as well as a server
side and on the client side we have
react client components and on the
server side we have react server
components. These days we also have
server actions basically your
traditional uh post put and delete
requests. If you want to update data
that's why you have server actions but
we can still create API endpoints as
well with these so-called route
handlers. So if you want to have an API
endpoint on your server, we can use that
for example for web hooks. All right. So
let's talk about these terms. So let's
start from the left there. So CSR is
client side rendering. And what do
people mean when they say that? Well, it
typically means that the app is rendered
in the client side. So this is
traditionally how you would learn React
and how you would build React
applications. React would run only in
the client side, only in the browser.
Now what does that mean? Well, let's say
I have some blog. So, here I have a
homepage. I have a /post page. And here
I have the individual post page. So,
title and some content here. So,
technically it is possible to compute
all of the markup for this on the
client. That is actually traditionally
if you were using React to build this

as it's called client side. For example,
if I want to add an upvote button here,
I could have an upvote component for
that and it could have some state,
right? Keeping track of how many times
an article was upvoted. And here we have
a button, some markup here. And then
here we are rendering that count into
the markup. So with client side
rendering, this is rendered in the
user's browser, right? So with rendering
I mean the statements inside the
component function body are run to
compute a final u output here of the
markup. Right? So initially the result
of that render would be something like
this. And this is just one component but
in a react app that would be the case
for all the components. All the
components would be would run only in
the user's browser. And actually if
you're just learning React that is
probably still how you learn it. Okay.
So this is like the traditional way of
of rendering you could say. And then
came along Nex.js. And with Nex.js these
days, we actually suddenly have a lot of
server side functionality. So actually a
lot of components in your app will not
run in the browser. They will actually
only run on the server side. So here we
have server side rendering. So here you
can imagine a React component. It's
being rendered on the server side. So if
we take a look at an example of a server
component in this app for example this
list of post this is also react
component and if this is rendered
meaning all the statements inside the
react component function body are run
only on the server side. So this does
not run in the browser. So we get the

side right this does not run in the

fetch data directly inside the the
function body here. I don't I don't need
some use effect. I can just do it
directly here. I can use my OM Prisma
here because it's all in a server
environment. In the user's browser, we
are typically not using Prisma, right?
So we can do this on the server side
thanks to this being a server component
that runs only on the server. In a next
application, very often most of the
components are actually server
components. If we take a look at a page
component for example, this is also a
react component. We just call it home

but still a react component and by
default actually these are server
components. So they run only on the

components by default are server
components. So a lot of things by
default are rendered on the server and
the output of that render is sent to the

still see it and that's why I can still
see a list of posts here. If I go here,
the output of that of that render is
still sent to me as the user here. So I
can still see it. So in an XJS app, like

then how does it work with like an

when the user clicks a button like we

to hook into an event in the browser.
These events do not run on the server.
There's no click event on the server.
Also, these React hooks cannot be used

it's too it's too wasteful right because

actually that is the default. So if I

with this new widget here in the corner.
It will tell you if a route it should

Okay. The alternative is dynamically
